A subset S of a ring R is called a subring if S is a subgroup with respect to the addition on R and a submonoid with respect to the multiplication on R. S inherits the laws of composition from R and is itself a ring.

Let $R$ be an integral domain and $p \in R$ a nonzero nonunit. $p$ is called irreducible if a factorization of type $p=x y$ with $x, y \in R$ implies $x \in R^{*}$ or $y \in R^{*}$. Furthermore, $p$ is called reducible if it is not irreducible.
Does the concept of a/an Subring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Irreducible element to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of an irreducible element is defined within the context of an integral domain, focusing on the properties of a specific element within that domain. The definition requires examining whether any factorization of the element into two other elements of the same ring leads to one of the factors being a unit (invertible element). This concept is self-contained and does not inherently require the notion of a subring. A subring, on the other hand, involves a subset of a ring that itself forms a ring under the same operations. The definition of an irreducible element does not rely on or involve any properties or structures of a subring. It solely depends on the properties of elements within the original ring (integral domain) itself. Therefore, understanding or defining a subring is not necessary for the concept of an irreducible element to be meaningful or valid.
